Name.documentation:
The name of the receipt rule. The name must:

  • This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-).

  • Start and end with a letter or number.

  • Contain less than 64 characters.

Enabled.zonbookDocumentation: If true, the receipt rule is active. The default value is false.
Enabled.documentation: If true, the receipt rule is active. The default value is false.

TlsPolicy.zonbookDocumentation: Specifies whether Amazon SES should require that incoming email is delivered over a connection encrypted with Transport Layer Security (TLS). If this parameter is set to Require, Amazon SES will bounce emails that are not received over TLS. The default is Optional.
TlsPolicy.documentation: Specifies whether Amazon SES should require that incoming email is delivered over a connection encrypted with Transport Layer Security (TLS). If this parameter is set to Require, Amazon SES will bounce emails that are not received over TLS. The default is Optional.

Recipients.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The recipient domains and email addresses that the receipt rule applies to. If this
            field is not specified, this rule will match all recipients under all verified
            domains.</para>
Recipients.documentation: The recipient domains and email addresses that the receipt rule applies to. If this field is not specified, this rule will match all recipients under all verified domains.

Actions.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>An ordered list of actions to perform on messages that match at least one of the
            recipient email addresses or domains specified in the receipt rule.</para>
Actions.documentation: An ordered list of actions to perform on messages that match at least one of the recipient email addresses or domains specified in the receipt rule.

TopicArn.zonbookDocumentation: The ARN of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the message is saved to the Amazon S3 bucket. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.
TopicArn.documentation: The ARN of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the message is saved to the Amazon S3 bucket. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.

BucketName.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The name of the Amazon S3 bucket that incoming email will be saved to.</para>
BucketName.documentation: The name of the Amazon S3 bucket that incoming email will be saved to.

ObjectKeyPrefix.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The key prefix of the Amazon S3 bucket. The key prefix is similar to a directory name that
            enables you to store similar data under the same directory in a bucket.</para>
ObjectKeyPrefix.documentation: The key prefix of the Amazon S3 bucket. The key prefix is similar to a directory name that enables you to store similar data under the same directory in a bucket.

KmsKeyArn.zonbookDocumentation: The customer master key that Amazon SES should use to encrypt your emails before saving them to the Amazon S3 bucket. You can use the default master key or a custom master key you created in AWS KMS as follows: To use the default master key, provide an ARN in the form of arn:aws:kms:REGION:ACCOUNT-ID-WITHOUT-HYPHENS:alias/aws/ses. For example, if your AWS account ID is 123456789012 and you want to use the default master key in the US West (Oregon) region, the ARN of the default master key would be arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:123456789012:alias/aws/ses. If you use the default master key, you don't need to perform any extra steps to give Amazon SES permission to use the key. To use a custom master key you created in AWS KMS, provide the ARN of the master key and ensure that you add a statement to your key's policy to give Amazon SES permission to use it. For more information about giving permissions, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide. For more information about key policies, see the AWS KMS Developer Guide. If you do not specify a master key, Amazon SES will not encrypt your emails. Your mail is encrypted by Amazon SES using the Amazon S3 encryption client before the mail is submitted to Amazon S3 for storage. It is not encrypted using Amazon S3 server-side encryption. This means that you must use the Amazon S3 encryption client to decrypt the email after retrieving it from Amazon S3, as the service has no access to use your AWS KMS keys for decryption. This encryption client is currently available with the AWS SDK for Java and AWS SDK for Ruby only. For more information about client-side encryption using AWS KMS master keys, see the Amazon S3 Developer Guide.
KmsKeyArn.documentation:
The customer master key that Amazon SES should use to encrypt your emails before saving them to the Amazon S3 bucket. You can use the default master key or a custom master key you created in AWS KMS as follows:

  • To use the default master key, provide an ARN in the form of arn:aws:kms:REGION:ACCOUNT-ID-WITHOUT-HYPHENS:alias/aws/ses. For example, if your AWS account ID is 123456789012 and you want to use the default master key in the US West (Oregon) region, the ARN of the default master key would be arn:aws:kms:us-west-2:123456789012:alias/aws/ses. If you use the default master key, you don't need to perform any extra steps to give Amazon SES permission to use the key.

  • To use a custom master key you created in AWS KMS, provide the ARN of the master key and ensure that you add a statement to your key's policy to give Amazon SES permission to use it. For more information about giving permissions, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

For more information about key policies, see the AWS KMS Developer Guide. If you do not specify a master key, Amazon SES will not encrypt your emails.

Your mail is encrypted by Amazon SES using the Amazon S3 encryption client before the mail is submitted to Amazon S3 for storage. It is not encrypted using Amazon S3 server-side encryption. This means that you must use the Amazon S3 encryption client to decrypt the email after retrieving it from Amazon S3, as the service has no access to use your AWS KMS keys for decryption. This encryption client is currently available with the AWS SDK for Java and AWS SDK for Ruby only. For more information about client-side encryption using AWS KMS master keys, see the Amazon S3 Developer Guide.

S3Action.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Saves the received message to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket and, optionally, publishes a
            notification to Amazon SNS.</para>
S3Action.documentation: Saves the received message to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket and, optionally, publishes a notification to Amazon SNS.

TopicArn.zonbookDocumentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the bounce action is taken. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.
TopicArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the bounce action is taken. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.

SmtpReplyCode.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The SMTP reply code, as defined by <ulink url="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5321">RFC 5321</ulink>.</para>
SmtpReplyCode.documentation: The SMTP reply code, as defined by RFC 5321.

StatusCode.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The SMTP enhanced status code, as defined by <ulink url="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3463">RFC 3463</ulink>.</para>
StatusCode.documentation: The SMTP enhanced status code, as defined by RFC 3463.

Message.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Human-readable text to include in the bounce message.</para>
Message.documentation: Human-readable text to include in the bounce message.

Sender.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The email address of the sender of the bounced email. This is the address from which
            the bounce message will be sent.</para>
Sender.documentation: The email address of the sender of the bounced email. This is the address from which the bounce message will be sent.

BounceAction.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Rejects the received email by returning a bounce response to the sender and,
            optionally, publishes a notification to Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS).</para>
BounceAction.documentation: Rejects the received email by returning a bounce response to the sender and, optionally, publishes a notification to Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS).

TopicArn.zonbookDocumentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the WorkMail action is called. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.
TopicArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the WorkMail action is called. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.

OrganizationArn.zonbookDocumentation: The ARN of the Amazon WorkMail organization. An example of an Amazon WorkMail organization ARN is arn:aws:workmail:us-west-2:123456789012:organization/m-68755160c4cb4e29a2b2f8fb58f359d7. For information about Amazon WorkMail organizations, see the Amazon WorkMail Administrator Guide.
OrganizationArn.documentation: The ARN of the Amazon WorkMail organization. An example of an Amazon WorkMail organization ARN is arn:aws:workmail:us-west-2:123456789012:organization/m-68755160c4cb4e29a2b2f8fb58f359d7. For information about Amazon WorkMail organizations, see the Amazon WorkMail Administrator Guide.

WorkmailAction.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Calls Amazon WorkMail and, optionally, publishes a notification to Amazon
            Amazon SNS.</para>
WorkmailAction.documentation: Calls Amazon WorkMail and, optionally, publishes a notification to Amazon Amazon SNS.

TopicArn.zonbookDocumentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the Lambda action is taken. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.
TopicArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the Lambda action is taken. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.

FunctionArn.zonbookDocumentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the AWS Lambda function. An example of an AWS Lambda function ARN is arn:aws:lambda:us-west-2:account-id:function:MyFunction. For more information about AWS Lambda, see the AWS Lambda Developer Guide.
FunctionArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the AWS Lambda function. An example of an AWS Lambda function ARN is arn:aws:lambda:us-west-2:account-id:function:MyFunction. For more information about AWS Lambda, see the AWS Lambda Developer Guide.

InvocationType.zonbookDocumentation: The invocation type of the AWS Lambda function. An invocation type of RequestResponse means that the execution of the function will immediately result in a response, and a value of Event means that the function will be invoked asynchronously. The default value is Event. For information about AWS Lambda invocation types, see the AWS Lambda Developer Guide. There is a 30-second timeout on RequestResponse invocations. You should use Event invocation in most cases. Use RequestResponse only when you want to make a mail flow decision, such as whether to stop the receipt rule or the receipt rule set.
InvocationType.documentation:
The invocation type of the AWS Lambda function. An invocation type of RequestResponse means that the execution of the function will immediately result in a response, and a value of Event means that the function will be invoked asynchronously. The default value is Event. For information about AWS Lambda invocation types, see the AWS Lambda Developer Guide.

There is a 30-second timeout on RequestResponse invocations. You should use Event invocation in most cases. Use RequestResponse only when you want to make a mail flow decision, such as whether to stop the receipt rule or the receipt rule set.

LambdaAction.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Calls an AWS Lambda function, and optionally, publishes a notification to Amazon SNS.</para>
LambdaAction.documentation: Calls an AWS Lambda function, and optionally, publishes a notification to Amazon SNS.

Scope.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The name of the RuleSet that is being stopped.</para>
Scope.documentation: The name of the RuleSet that is being stopped.

TopicArn.zonbookDocumentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the stop action is taken. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.
TopicArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify when the stop action is taken. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.

StopAction.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Terminates the evaluation of the receipt rule set and optionally publishes a
            notification to Amazon SNS.</para>
StopAction.documentation: Terminates the evaluation of the receipt rule set and optionally publishes a notification to Amazon SNS.

HeaderName.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the header to add. Must be between 1 and 50 characters, inclusive, and
            consist of alphanumeric (a-z, A-Z, 0-9) characters and dashes only.</para>
HeaderName.documentation: The name of the header to add. Must be between 1 and 50 characters, inclusive, and consist of alphanumeric (a-z, A-Z, 0-9) characters and dashes only.

HeaderValue.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Must be less than 2048 characters, and must not contain newline characters ("\r" or
            "\n").</para>
HeaderValue.documentation: Must be less than 2048 characters, and must not contain newline characters ("\r" or "\n").

AddHeaderAction.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Adds a header to the received email.</para>
AddHeaderAction.documentation: Adds a header to the received email.

TopicArn.zonbookDocumentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.
TopicArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic to notify. An example of an Amazon SNS topic ARN is arn:aws:sns:us-west-2:123456789012:MyTopic. For more information about Amazon SNS topics, see the Amazon SNS Developer Guide.

Encoding.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The encoding to use for the email within the Amazon SNS notification. UTF-8 is easier to
            use, but may not preserve all special characters when a message was encoded with a
            different encoding format. Base64 preserves all special characters. The default value is
            UTF-8.</para>
Encoding.documentation: The encoding to use for the email within the Amazon SNS notification. UTF-8 is easier to use, but may not preserve all special characters when a message was encoded with a different encoding format. Base64 preserves all special characters. The default value is UTF-8.

SNSAction.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Publishes the email content within a notification to Amazon SNS.</para>
SNSAction.documentation: Publishes the email content within a notification to Amazon SNS.

members.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>An action that Amazon SES can take when it receives an email on behalf of one or more email
            addresses or domains that you own. An instance of this data type can represent only one
            action.</para>
        <para>For information about setting up receipt rules, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email-receipt-rules.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
members.documentation:
An action that Amazon SES can take when it receives an email on behalf of one or more email addresses or domains that you own. An instance of this data type can represent only one action.

For information about setting up receipt rules, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

ScanEnabled.zonbookDocumentation: If true, then messages that this receipt rule applies to are scanned for spam and viruses. The default value is false.
ScanEnabled.documentation: If true, then messages that this receipt rule applies to are scanned for spam and viruses. The default value is false.

members.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Receipt rules enable you to specify which actions Amazon SES should take when it receives
            mail on behalf of one or more email addresses or domains that you own.</para>
        <para>Each receipt rule defines a set of email addresses or domains that it applies to. If
            the email addresses or domains match at least one recipient address of the message,
            Amazon SES executes all of the receipt rule's actions on the message.</para>
        <para>For information about setting up receipt rules, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email-receipt-rules.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
members.documentation:
Receipt rules enable you to specify which actions Amazon SES should take when it receives mail on behalf of one or more email addresses or domains that you own.

Each receipt rule defines a set of email addresses or domains that it applies to. If the email addresses or domains match at least one recipient address of the message, Amazon SES executes all of the receipt rule's actions on the message.

For information about setting up receipt rules, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

output.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents the metadata and receipt rules for the receipt rule set that is currently
            active.</para>
output.documentation: Represents the metadata and receipt rules for the receipt rule set that is currently active.

DescribeActiveReceiptRuleSet.documentation:
Returns the metadata and receipt rules for the receipt rule set that is currently active.

For information about setting up receipt rule sets, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

SetActiveReceiptRuleSet.name: SetActiveReceiptRuleSet

RuleSetName.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the receipt rule set to make active. Setting this value to null disables
            all email receiving.</para>
RuleSetName.documentation: The name of the receipt rule set to make active. Setting this value to null disables all email receiving.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to set a receipt rule set as the active receipt rule set. You use
            receipt rule sets to receive email with Amazon SES. For more information, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email-concepts.html">Amazon SES Developer Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to set a receipt rule set as the active receipt rule set. You use receipt rule sets to receive email with Amazon SES. For more information, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>An empty element returned on a successful request.</para>
output.documentation: An empty element returned on a successful request.

Name.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Indicates that the named receipt rule set does not exist.</para>
Name.documentation: Indicates that the named receipt rule set does not exist.

errors.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Indicates that the provided receipt rule set does not exist.</para>
errors.documentation: Indicates that the provided receipt rule set does not exist.

SetActiveReceiptRuleSet.documentation:
Sets the specified receipt rule set as the active receipt rule set.

To disable your email-receiving through Amazon SES completely, you can call this API with RuleSetName set to null.

For information about managing receipt rule sets, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

CreateReceiptFilter.name: CreateReceiptFilter

Name.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the IP address filter. The name must:</para>
        <itemizedlist>
            <listitem>
                <para>This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9),
                    underscores (_), or dashes (-).</para>
            </listitem>
            <listitem>
                <para>Start and end with a letter or number.</para>
            </listitem>
            <listitem>
                <para>Contain less than 64 characters.</para>
            </listitem>
        </itemizedlist>
Name.documentation:
The name of the IP address filter. The name must:

  • This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-).

  • Start and end with a letter or number.

  • Contain less than 64 characters.

Policy.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Indicates whether to block or allow incoming mail from the specified IP
            addresses.</para>
Policy.documentation: Indicates whether to block or allow incoming mail from the specified IP addresses.

Cidr.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>A single IP address or a range of IP addresses that you want to block or allow,
            specified in Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) notation. An example of a single
            email address is 10.0.0.1. An example of a range of IP addresses is 10.0.0.1/24. For
            more information about CIDR notation, see <ulink url="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2317">RFC 2317</ulink>.</para>
Cidr.documentation: A single IP address or a range of IP addresses that you want to block or allow, specified in Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) notation. An example of a single email address is 10.0.0.1. An example of a range of IP addresses is 10.0.0.1/24. For more information about CIDR notation, see RFC 2317.

IpFilter.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>A structure that provides the IP addresses to block or allow, and whether to block or
            allow incoming mail from them.</para>
IpFilter.documentation: A structure that provides the IP addresses to block or allow, and whether to block or allow incoming mail from them.

Filter.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>A data structure that describes the IP address filter to create, which consists of a
            name, an IP address range, and whether to allow or block mail from it.</para>
Filter.documentation: A data structure that describes the IP address filter to create, which consists of a name, an IP address range, and whether to allow or block mail from it.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to create a new IP address filter. You use IP address filters
            when you receive email with Amazon SES. For more information, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email-concepts.html">Amazon SES Developer Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to create a new IP address filter. You use IP address filters when you receive email with Amazon SES. For more information, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>An empty element returned on a successful request.</para>
output.documentation: An empty element returned on a successful request.

errors.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Indicates that a resource could not be created because of service limits. For a list
            of Amazon SES limits, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/limits.html">Amazon SES Developer
            Guide</ulink>.</para>
errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource could not be created because of service limits. For a list of Amazon SES limits, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

Name.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Indicates that a resource could not be created because the resource name already
            exists.</para>
Name.documentation: Indicates that a resource could not be created because the resource name already exists.

errors.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Indicates that a resource could not be created because of a naming conflict.</para>
errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource could not be created because of a naming conflict.

CreateReceiptFilter.documentation:
Creates a new IP address filter.

For information about setting up IP address filters, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

DeleteReceiptFilter.name: DeleteReceiptFilter

FilterName.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The name of the IP address filter to delete.</para>
FilterName.documentation: The name of the IP address filter to delete.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to delete an IP address filter. You use IP address filters when
            you receive email with Amazon SES. For more information, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email-concepts.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to delete an IP address filter. You use IP address filters when you receive email with Amazon SES. For more information, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>An empty element returned on a successful request.</para>
output.documentation: An empty element returned on a successful request.

DeleteReceiptFilter.documentation:
Deletes the specified IP address filter.

For information about managing IP address filters, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

ListReceiptFilters.name: ListReceiptFilters

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to list the IP address filters that exist under your AWS account.
            You use IP address filters when you receive email with Amazon SES. For more information, see
            the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email-concepts.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to list the IP address filters that exist under your AWS account. You use IP address filters when you receive email with Amazon SES. For more information, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

Filters.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>A list of IP address filter data structures, which each consist of a name, an IP
            address range, and whether to allow or block mail from it.</para>
Filters.documentation: A list of IP address filter data structures, which each consist of a name, an IP address range, and whether to allow or block mail from it.

Name.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the IP address filter. The name must:</para>
        <itemizedlist>
            <listitem>
                <para>This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9),
                    underscores (_), or dashes (-).</para>
            </listitem>
            <listitem>
                <para>Start and end with a letter or number.</para>
            </listitem>
            <listitem>
                <para>Contain less than 64 characters.</para>
            </listitem>
        </itemizedlist>
Name.documentation:
The name of the IP address filter. The name must:

  • This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-).

  • Start and end with a letter or number.

  • Contain less than 64 characters.

Policy.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Indicates whether to block or allow incoming mail from the specified IP
            addresses.</para>
Policy.documentation: Indicates whether to block or allow incoming mail from the specified IP addresses.

Cidr.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>A single IP address or a range of IP addresses that you want to block or allow,
            specified in Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) notation. An example of a single
            email address is 10.0.0.1. An example of a range of IP addresses is 10.0.0.1/24. For
            more information about CIDR notation, see <ulink url="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2317">RFC 2317</ulink>.</para>
Cidr.documentation: A single IP address or a range of IP addresses that you want to block or allow, specified in Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) notation. An example of a single email address is 10.0.0.1. An example of a range of IP addresses is 10.0.0.1/24. For more information about CIDR notation, see RFC 2317.

IpFilter.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>A structure that provides the IP addresses to block or allow, and whether to block or
            allow incoming mail from them.</para>
IpFilter.documentation: A structure that provides the IP addresses to block or allow, and whether to block or allow incoming mail from them.

members.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>A receipt IP address filter enables you to specify whether to accept or reject mail
            originating from an IP address or range of IP addresses.</para>
        <para>For information about setting up IP address filters, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email-ip-filters.html">Amazon SES Developer Guide</ulink>.</para>
members.documentation:
A receipt IP address filter enables you to specify whether to accept or reject mail originating from an IP address or range of IP addresses.

For information about setting up IP address filters, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>A list of IP address filters that exist under your AWS account.</para>
output.documentation: A list of IP address filters that exist under your AWS account.

ListReceiptFilters.documentation:
Lists the IP address filters associated with your AWS account in the current AWS Region.

For information about managing IP address filters, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

SendBounce.name: SendBounce

OriginalMessageId.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The message ID of the message to be bounced.</para>
OriginalMessageId.documentation: The message ID of the message to be bounced.

BounceSender.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The address to use in the "From" header of the bounce message. This must be an
            identity that you have verified with Amazon SES.</para>
BounceSender.documentation: The address to use in the "From" header of the bounce message. This must be an identity that you have verified with Amazon SES.

Explanation.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Human-readable text for the bounce message to explain the failure. If not specified,
            the text will be auto-generated based on the bounced recipient information.</para>
Explanation.documentation: Human-readable text for the bounce message to explain the failure. If not specified, the text will be auto-generated based on the bounced recipient information.

ReportingMta.zonbookDocumentation: The reporting MTA that attempted to deliver the message, formatted as specified in RFC 3464 (mta-name-type; mta-name). The default value is dns; inbound-smtp.[region].amazonaws.com.
ReportingMta.documentation: The reporting MTA that attempted to deliver the message, formatted as specified in RFC 3464 (mta-name-type; mta-name). The default value is dns; inbound-smtp.[region].amazonaws.com.

ArrivalDate.zonbookDocumentation: <para>When the message was received by the reporting mail transfer agent (MTA), in <ulink url="https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc0822.txt">RFC 822</ulink> date-time format.</para>
ArrivalDate.documentation: When the message was received by the reporting mail transfer agent (MTA), in RFC 822 date-time format.

ExtensionFields.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Additional X-headers to include in the DSN.</para>
ExtensionFields.documentation: Additional X-headers to include in the DSN.

Name.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the header to add. Must be between 1 and 50 characters, inclusive, and
            consist of alphanumeric (a-z, A-Z, 0-9) characters and dashes only.</para>
Name.documentation: The name of the header to add. Must be between 1 and 50 characters, inclusive, and consist of alphanumeric (a-z, A-Z, 0-9) characters and dashes only.

Value.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The value of the header to add. Must be less than 2048 characters, and must not
            contain newline characters ("\r" or "\n").</para>
Value.documentation: The value of the header to add. Must be less than 2048 characters, and must not contain newline characters ("\r" or "\n").

members.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Additional X-headers to include in the Delivery Status Notification (DSN) when an
            email that Amazon SES receives on your behalf bounces.</para>
        <para>For information about receiving email through Amazon SES, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email.html">Amazon SES
                Developer Guide</ulink>.</para>
members.documentation:
Additional X-headers to include in the Delivery Status Notification (DSN) when an email that Amazon SES receives on your behalf bounces.

For information about receiving email through Amazon SES, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

MessageDsn.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Message-related DSN fields. If not specified, Amazon SES will choose the values.</para>
MessageDsn.documentation: Message-related DSN fields. If not specified, Amazon SES will choose the values.

BouncedRecipientInfoList.zonbookDocumentation: A list of recipients of the bounced message, including the information required to create the Delivery Status Notifications (DSNs) for the recipients. You must specify at least one BouncedRecipientInfo in the list.
BouncedRecipientInfoList.documentation: A list of recipients of the bounced message, including the information required to create the Delivery Status Notifications (DSNs) for the recipients. You must specify at least one BouncedRecipientInfo in the list.

Recipient.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The email address of the recipient of the bounced email.</para>
Recipient.documentation: The email address of the recipient of the bounced email.

RecipientArn.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the identity
            that is associated with the sending authorization policy that permits you to receive
            email for the recipient of the bounced email. For more information about sending
            authorization, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
RecipientArn.documentation: This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that permits you to receive email for the recipient of the bounced email. For more information about sending authorization, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

BounceType.zonbookDocumentation: The reason for the bounce. You must provide either this parameter or RecipientDsnFields.
BounceType.documentation: The reason for the bounce. You must provide either this parameter or RecipientDsnFields.

FinalRecipient.zonbookDocumentation: The email address that the message was ultimately delivered to. This corresponds to the Final-Recipient in the DSN. If not specified, FinalRecipient will be set to the Recipient specified in the BouncedRecipientInfo structure. Either FinalRecipient or the recipient in BouncedRecipientInfo must be a recipient of the original bounced message. Do not prepend the FinalRecipient email address with rfc 822;, as described in RFC 3798.
FinalRecipient.documentation:
The email address that the message was ultimately delivered to. This corresponds to the Final-Recipient in the DSN. If not specified, FinalRecipient will be set to the Recipient specified in the BouncedRecipientInfo structure. Either FinalRecipient or the recipient in BouncedRecipientInfo must be a recipient of the original bounced message.

Do not prepend the FinalRecipient email address with rfc 822;, as described in RFC 3798.

Action.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The action performed by the reporting mail transfer agent (MTA) as a result of its
            attempt to deliver the message to the recipient address. This is required by <ulink url="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3464">RFC 3464</ulink>.</para>
Action.documentation: The action performed by the reporting mail transfer agent (MTA) as a result of its attempt to deliver the message to the recipient address. This is required by RFC 3464.

RemoteMta.zonbookDocumentation: The MTA to which the remote MTA attempted to deliver the message, formatted as specified in RFC 3464 (mta-name-type; mta-name). This parameter typically applies only to propagating synchronous bounces.
RemoteMta.documentation: The MTA to which the remote MTA attempted to deliver the message, formatted as specified in RFC 3464 (mta-name-type; mta-name). This parameter typically applies only to propagating synchronous bounces.

Status.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The status code that indicates what went wrong. This is required by <ulink url="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3464">RFC 3464</ulink>.</para>
Status.documentation: The status code that indicates what went wrong. This is required by RFC 3464.

DiagnosticCode.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>An extended explanation of what went wrong; this is usually an SMTP response. See
                <ulink url="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3463">RFC 3463</ulink> for the correct
            formatting of this parameter.</para>
DiagnosticCode.documentation: An extended explanation of what went wrong; this is usually an SMTP response. See RFC 3463 for the correct formatting of this parameter.

LastAttemptDate.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The time the final delivery attempt was made, in <ulink url="https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc0822.txt">RFC 822</ulink> date-time format.</para>
LastAttemptDate.documentation: The time the final delivery attempt was made, in RFC 822 date-time format.

ExtensionFields.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Additional X-headers to include in the DSN.</para>
ExtensionFields.documentation: Additional X-headers to include in the DSN.

Name.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the header to add. Must be between 1 and 50 characters, inclusive, and
            consist of alphanumeric (a-z, A-Z, 0-9) characters and dashes only.</para>
Name.documentation: The name of the header to add. Must be between 1 and 50 characters, inclusive, and consist of alphanumeric (a-z, A-Z, 0-9) characters and dashes only.

Value.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The value of the header to add. Must be less than 2048 characters, and must not
            contain newline characters ("\r" or "\n").</para>
Value.documentation: The value of the header to add. Must be less than 2048 characters, and must not contain newline characters ("\r" or "\n").

members.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Additional X-headers to include in the Delivery Status Notification (DSN) when an
            email that Amazon SES receives on your behalf bounces.</para>
        <para>For information about receiving email through Amazon SES, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email.html">Amazon SES
                Developer Guide</ulink>.</para>
members.documentation:
Additional X-headers to include in the Delivery Status Notification (DSN) when an email that Amazon SES receives on your behalf bounces.

For information about receiving email through Amazon SES, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

RecipientDsnFields.zonbookDocumentation: Recipient-related DSN fields, most of which would normally be filled in automatically when provided with a BounceType. You must provide either this parameter or BounceType.
RecipientDsnFields.documentation: Recipient-related DSN fields, most of which would normally be filled in automatically when provided with a BounceType. You must provide either this parameter or BounceType.

members.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Recipient-related information to include in the Delivery Status Notification (DSN)
            when an email that Amazon SES receives on your behalf bounces.</para>
        <para>For information about receiving email through Amazon SES, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/receiving-email.html">Amazon SES
                Developer Guide</ulink>.</para>
members.documentation:
Recipient-related information to include in the Delivery Status Notification (DSN) when an email that Amazon SES receives on your behalf bounces.

For information about receiving email through Amazon SES, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

BounceSenderArn.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the identity
            that is associated with the sending authorization policy that permits you to use the
            address in the "From" header of the bounce. For more information about sending
            authorization, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
BounceSenderArn.documentation: This parameter is used only for sending authorization. It is the ARN of the identity that is associated with the sending authorization policy that permits you to use the address in the "From" header of the bounce. For more information about sending authorization, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to send a bounce message to the sender of an email you received
            through Amazon SES.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to send a bounce message to the sender of an email you received through Amazon SES.

MessageId.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The message ID of the bounce message.</para>
MessageId.documentation: The message ID of the bounce message.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Represents a unique message ID.</para>
output.documentation: Represents a unique message ID.

errors.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Indicates that the action failed, and the message could not be sent. Check the error
            stack for more information about what caused the error.</para>
errors.documentation: Indicates that the action failed, and the message could not be sent. Check the error stack for more information about what caused the error.

SendBounce.documentation:
Generates and sends a bounce message to the sender of an email you received through Amazon SES. You can only use this API on an email up to 24 hours after you receive it.

You cannot use this API to send generic bounces for mail that was not received by Amazon SES.

For information about receiving email through Amazon SES, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

PutIdentityPolicy.name: PutIdentityPolicy

Identity.zonbookDocumentation: The identity that the policy will apply to. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: user@example.com, example.com, arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com. To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.
Identity.documentation:
The identity that the policy will apply to. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: user@example.com, example.com, arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com.

To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

PolicyName.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the policy.</para>
        <para>The policy name cannot exceed 64 characters and can only include alphanumeric
            characters, dashes, and underscores.</para>
PolicyName.documentation:
The name of the policy.

The policy name cannot exceed 64 characters and can only include alphanumeric characters, dashes, and underscores.

Policy.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The text of the policy in JSON format. The policy cannot exceed 4 KB.</para>
        <para>For information about the syntax of sending authorization policies, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization-policies.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>. </para>
Policy.documentation:
The text of the policy in JSON format. The policy cannot exceed 4 KB.

For information about the syntax of sending authorization policies, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to add or update a sending authorization policy for an identity.
            Sending authorization is an Amazon SES feature that enables you to authorize other senders to
            use your identities. For information, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to add or update a sending authorization policy for an identity. Sending authorization is an Amazon SES feature that enables you to authorize other senders to use your identities. For information, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>An empty element returned on a successful request.</para>
output.documentation: An empty element returned on a successful request.

errors.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Indicates that the provided policy is invalid. Check the error stack for more
            information about what caused the error.</para>
errors.documentation: Indicates that the provided policy is invalid. Check the error stack for more information about what caused the error.

PutIdentityPolicy.documentation:
Adds or updates a sending authorization policy for the specified identity (an email address or a domain).

This API is for the identity owner only. If you have not verified the identity, this API will return an error.

Sending authorization is a feature that enables an identity owner to authorize other senders to use its identities. For information about using sending authorization, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

GetIdentityPolicies.name: GetIdentityPolicies

Identity.zonbookDocumentation: The identity for which the policies will be retrieved. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: user@example.com, example.com, arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com. To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.
Identity.documentation:
The identity for which the policies will be retrieved. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: user@example.com, example.com, arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com.

To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

PolicyNames.zonbookDocumentation: A list of the names of policies to be retrieved. You can retrieve a maximum of 20 policies at a time. If you do not know the names of the policies that are attached to the identity, you can use ListIdentityPolicies.
PolicyNames.documentation: A list of the names of policies to be retrieved. You can retrieve a maximum of 20 policies at a time. If you do not know the names of the policies that are attached to the identity, you can use ListIdentityPolicies.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to return the requested sending authorization policies for an
            identity. Sending authorization is an Amazon SES feature that enables you to authorize other
            senders to use your identities. For information, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to return the requested sending authorization policies for an identity. Sending authorization is an Amazon SES feature that enables you to authorize other senders to use your identities. For information, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

Policies.zonbookDocumentation: <para>A map of policy names to policies.</para>
Policies.documentation: A map of policy names to policies.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Represents the requested sending authorization policies.</para>
output.documentation: Represents the requested sending authorization policies.

GetIdentityPolicies.documentation:
Returns the requested sending authorization policies for the given identity (an email address or a domain). The policies are returned as a map of policy names to policy contents. You can retrieve a maximum of 20 policies at a time.

This API is for the identity owner only. If you have not verified the identity, this API will return an error.

Sending authorization is a feature that enables an identity owner to authorize other senders to use its identities. For information about using sending authorization, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

DeleteIdentityPolicy.name: DeleteIdentityPolicy

Identity.zonbookDocumentation: The identity that is associated with the policy that you want to delete. You can specify the identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: user@example.com, example.com, arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com. To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.
Identity.documentation:
The identity that is associated with the policy that you want to delete. You can specify the identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: user@example.com, example.com, arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com.

To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

PolicyName.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The name of the policy to be deleted.</para>
PolicyName.documentation: The name of the policy to be deleted.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to delete a sending authorization policy for an identity. Sending
            authorization is an Amazon SES feature that enables you to authorize other senders to use
            your identities. For information, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to delete a sending authorization policy for an identity. Sending authorization is an Amazon SES feature that enables you to authorize other senders to use your identities. For information, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>An empty element returned on a successful request.</para>
output.documentation: An empty element returned on a successful request.

DeleteIdentityPolicy.documentation:
Deletes the specified sending authorization policy for the given identity (an email address or a domain). This API returns successfully even if a policy with the specified name does not exist.

This API is for the identity owner only. If you have not verified the identity, this API will return an error.

Sending authorization is a feature that enables an identity owner to authorize other senders to use its identities. For information about using sending authorization, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

ListIdentityPolicies.name: ListIdentityPolicies

Identity.zonbookDocumentation: The identity that is associated with the policy for which the policies will be listed. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: user@example.com, example.com, arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com. To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.
Identity.documentation:
The identity that is associated with the policy for which the policies will be listed. You can specify an identity by using its name or by using its Amazon Resource Name (ARN). Examples: user@example.com, example.com, arn:aws:ses:us-east-1:123456789012:identity/example.com.

To successfully call this API, you must own the identity.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to return a list of sending authorization policies that are
            attached to an identity. Sending authorization is an Amazon SES feature that enables you to
            authorize other senders to use your identities. For information, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/sending-authorization.html">Amazon SES Developer Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to return a list of sending authorization policies that are attached to an identity. Sending authorization is an Amazon SES feature that enables you to authorize other senders to use your identities. For information, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

PolicyNames.zonbookDocumentation: <para>A list of names of policies that apply to the specified identity.</para>
PolicyNames.documentation: A list of names of policies that apply to the specified identity.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>A list of names of sending authorization policies that apply to an identity.</para>
output.documentation: A list of names of sending authorization policies that apply to an identity.

ListIdentityPolicies.documentation:
Returns a list of sending authorization policies that are attached to the given identity (an email address or a domain). This API returns only a list. If you want the actual policy content, you can use GetIdentityPolicies.

This API is for the identity owner only. If you have not verified the identity, this API will return an error.

Sending authorization is a feature that enables an identity owner to authorize other senders to use its identities. For information about using sending authorization, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

CreateConfigurationSet.name: CreateConfigurationSet

Name.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the configuration set. The name must meet the following
            requirements:</para>
        <itemizedlist>
            <listitem>
                <para>Contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes
                    (-).</para>
            </listitem>
            <listitem>
                <para>Contain 64 characters or fewer.</para>
            </listitem>
        </itemizedlist>
Name.documentation:
The name of the configuration set. The name must meet the following requirements:

  • Contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-).

  • Contain 64 characters or fewer.

ConfigurationSet.zonbookDocumentation: <para>A data structure that contains the name of the configuration set.</para>
ConfigurationSet.documentation: A data structure that contains the name of the configuration set.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to create a configuration set. Configuration sets enable you to
            publish email sending events. For information about using configuration sets, see the
                <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/monitor-sending-activity.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to create a configuration set. Configuration sets enable you to publish email sending events. For information about using configuration sets, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>An empty element returned on a successful request.</para>
output.documentation: An empty element returned on a successful request.

ConfigurationSetName.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Indicates that the configuration set does not exist.</para>
ConfigurationSetName.documentation: Indicates that the configuration set does not exist.

errors.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Indicates that the configuration set could not be created because of a naming
            conflict.</para>
errors.documentation: Indicates that the configuration set could not be created because of a naming conflict.

errors.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Indicates that the configuration set is invalid. See the error message for
            details.</para>
errors.documentation: Indicates that the configuration set is invalid. See the error message for details.

errors.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Indicates that a resource could not be created because of service limits. For a list
            of Amazon SES limits, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/limits.html">Amazon SES Developer
            Guide</ulink>.</para>
errors.documentation: Indicates that a resource could not be created because of service limits. For a list of Amazon SES limits, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

CreateConfigurationSet.documentation:
Creates a configuration set.

Configuration sets enable you to publish email sending events. For information about using configuration sets, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

DeleteConfigurationSet.name: DeleteConfigurationSet

ConfigurationSetName.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The name of the configuration set to delete.</para>
ConfigurationSetName.documentation: The name of the configuration set to delete.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to delete a configuration set. Configuration sets enable you to
            publish email sending events. For information about using configuration sets, see the
                <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/monitor-sending-activity.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to delete a configuration set. Configuration sets enable you to publish email sending events. For information about using configuration sets, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

output.zonbookDocumentation: <para>An empty element returned on a successful request.</para>
output.documentation: An empty element returned on a successful request.

ConfigurationSetName.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Indicates that the configuration set does not exist.</para>
ConfigurationSetName.documentation: Indicates that the configuration set does not exist.

errors.zonbookDocumentation: <para>Indicates that the configuration set does not exist.</para>
errors.documentation: Indicates that the configuration set does not exist.

DeleteConfigurationSet.documentation:
Deletes a configuration set. Configuration sets enable you to publish email sending events. For information about using configuration sets, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

DescribeConfigurationSet.name: DescribeConfigurationSet

ConfigurationSetName.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The name of the configuration set to describe.</para>
ConfigurationSetName.documentation: The name of the configuration set to describe.

ConfigurationSetAttributeNames.zonbookDocumentation: <para>A list of configuration set attributes to return.</para>
ConfigurationSetAttributeNames.documentation: A list of configuration set attributes to return.

input.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>Represents a request to return the details of a configuration set. Configuration sets
            enable you to publish email sending events. For information about using configuration
            sets, see the <ulink type="documentation" url="ses/latest/DeveloperGuide/monitor-sending-activity.html">Amazon SES Developer
                Guide</ulink>.</para>
input.documentation: Represents a request to return the details of a configuration set. Configuration sets enable you to publish email sending events. For information about using configuration sets, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

Name.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the configuration set. The name must meet the following
            requirements:</para>
        <itemizedlist>
            <listitem>
                <para>Contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes
                    (-).</para>
            </listitem>
            <listitem>
                <para>Contain 64 characters or fewer.</para>
            </listitem>
        </itemizedlist>
Name.documentation:
The name of the configuration set. The name must meet the following requirements:

  • Contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-).

  • Contain 64 characters or fewer.

ConfigurationSet.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The configuration set object associated with the specified configuration set.</para>
ConfigurationSet.documentation: The configuration set object associated with the specified configuration set.

EventDestinations.zonbookDocumentation: <para>A list of event destinations associated with the configuration set. </para>
EventDestinations.documentation: A list of event destinations associated with the configuration set.

Name.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of the event destination. The name must:</para>
        <itemizedlist>
            <listitem>
                <para>This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9),
                    underscores (_), or dashes (-).</para>
            </listitem>
            <listitem>
                <para>Contain less than 64 characters.</para>
            </listitem>
        </itemizedlist>
Name.documentation:
The name of the event destination. The name must:

  • This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-).

  • Contain less than 64 characters.

Enabled.zonbookDocumentation: Sets whether Amazon SES publishes events to this destination when you send an email with the associated configuration set. Set to true to enable publishing to this destination; set to false to prevent publishing to this destination. The default value is false.
Enabled.documentation: Sets whether Amazon SES publishes events to this destination when you send an email with the associated configuration set. Set to true to enable publishing to this destination; set to false to prevent publishing to this destination. The default value is false.

MatchingEventTypes.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The type of email sending events to publish to the event destination.</para>
MatchingEventTypes.documentation: The type of email sending events to publish to the event destination.

IAMRoleARN.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The ARN of the IAM role under which Amazon SES publishes email sending events to the Amazon Kinesis Firehose
            stream.</para>
IAMRoleARN.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role under which Amazon SES publishes email sending events to the Amazon Kinesis Firehose stream.

DeliveryStreamARN.zonbookDocumentation: <para>The ARN of the Amazon Kinesis Firehose stream that email sending events should be published to.</para>
DeliveryStreamARN.documentation: The ARN of the Amazon Kinesis Firehose stream that email sending events should be published to.

KinesisFirehoseDestination.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>An object that contains the delivery stream ARN and the IAM role ARN associated with
            an Amazon Kinesis Firehose event destination.</para>
KinesisFirehoseDestination.documentation: An object that contains the delivery stream ARN and the IAM role ARN associated with an Amazon Kinesis Firehose event destination.

DimensionConfigurations.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>A list of dimensions upon which to categorize your emails when you publish email
            sending events to Amazon CloudWatch.</para>
DimensionConfigurations.documentation: A list of dimensions upon which to categorize your emails when you publish email sending events to Amazon CloudWatch.

DimensionName.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The name of an Amazon CloudWatch dimension associated with an email sending metric. The name
            must:</para>
        <itemizedlist>
            <listitem>
                <para>This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9),
                    underscores (_), or dashes (-).</para>
            </listitem>
            <listitem>
                <para>Contain less than 256 characters.</para>
            </listitem>
        </itemizedlist>
DimensionName.documentation:
The name of an Amazon CloudWatch dimension associated with an email sending metric. The name must:

  • This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-).

  • Contain less than 256 characters.

DimensionValueSource.zonbookDocumentation: The place where Amazon SES finds the value of a dimension to publish to Amazon CloudWatch. If you want Amazon SES to use the message tags that you specify using an X-SES-MESSAGE-TAGS header or a parameter to the SendEmail/SendRawEmail API, choose messageTag. If you want Amazon SES to use your own email headers, choose emailHeader.
DimensionValueSource.documentation: The place where Amazon SES finds the value of a dimension to publish to Amazon CloudWatch. If you want Amazon SES to use the message tags that you specify using an X-SES-MESSAGE-TAGS header or a parameter to the SendEmail/SendRawEmail API, choose messageTag. If you want Amazon SES to use your own email headers, choose emailHeader.

DefaultDimensionValue.zonbookDocumentation:
<para>The default value of the dimension that is published to Amazon CloudWatch if you do not provide
            the value of the dimension when you send an email. The default value must:</para>
        <itemizedlist>
            <listitem>
                <para>This value can only contain ASCII letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9),
                    underscores (_), or dashes (-).</para>
            </listitem>
            <listitem>
                <para>Contain less than 256 characters.</para>
            </listitem>
        </itemizedlist>
DefaultDimensionValue.documentation:

The default value is true. You can change this setting using .
SendingEnabled.documentation: Describes whether email sending is enabled or disabled for the configuration set. If the value is true, then Amazon SES will send emails that use the configuration set. If the value is false, Amazon SES will not send emails that use the configuration set. The default value is true. You can change this setting using UpdateConfigurationSetSendingEnabled.

ReputationMetricsEnabled.zonbookDocumentation: Describes whether or not Amazon SES publishes reputation metrics for the configuration set, such as bounce and complaint rates, to Amazon CloudWatch. If the value is true, reputation metrics are published. If the value is false, reputation metrics are not published. The default value is false.
ReputationMetricsEnabled.documentation:
Describes whether or not Amazon SES publishes reputation metrics for the configuration set, such as bounce and complaint rates, to Amazon CloudWatch.

If the value is true, reputation metrics are published. If the value is false, reputation metrics are not published. The default value is false.

LastFreshStart.zonbookDocumentation: The date and time at which the reputation metrics for the configuration set were last reset. Resetting these metrics is known as a fresh start. When you disable email sending for a configuration set using and later re-enable it, the reputation metrics for the configuration set (but not for the entire Amazon SES account) are reset. If email sending for the configuration set has never been disabled and later re-enabled, the value of this attribute is null.
LastFreshStart.documentation:
The date and time at which the reputation metrics for the configuration set were last reset. Resetting these metrics is known as a fresh start.

When you disable email sending for a configuration set using UpdateConfigurationSetSendingEnabled and later re-enable it, the reputation metrics for the configuration set (but not for the entire Amazon SES account) are reset.

If email sending for the configuration set has never been disabled and later re-enabled, the value of this attribute is null.

ListConfigurationSets.documentation:
Provides a list of the configuration sets associated with your Amazon SES account in the current AWS Region. For information about using configuration sets, see Monitoring Your Amazon SES Sending Activity in the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second. This operation will return up to 1,000 configuration sets each time it is run. If your Amazon SES account has more than 1,000 configuration sets, this operation will also return a NextToken element. You can then execute the ListConfigurationSets operation again, passing the NextToken parameter and the value of the NextToken element to retrieve additional results.

Creates a configuration set event destination.

When you create or update an event destination, you must provide one, and only one, destination. The destination can be CloudWatch, Amazon Kinesis Firehose, or Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS).

An event destination is the AWS service to which Amazon SES publishes the email sending events associated with a configuration set. For information about using configuration sets, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

UpdateConfigurationSetEventDestination.documentation:
Updates the event destination of a configuration set. Event destinations are associated with configuration sets, which enable you to publish email sending events to Amazon CloudWatch, Amazon Kinesis Firehose, or Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS). For information about using configuration sets, see Monitoring Your Amazon SES Sending Activity in the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

When you create or update an event destination, you must provide one, and only one, destination. The destination can be Amazon CloudWatch, Amazon Kinesis Firehose, or Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS).

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

UpdateConfigurationSetReputationMetricsE.documentation:
Enables or disables the publishing of reputation metrics for emails sent using a specific configuration set in a given AWS Region. Reputation metrics include bounce and complaint rates. These metrics are published to Amazon CloudWatch. By using CloudWatch, you can create alarms when bounce or complaint rates exceed certain thresholds.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

UpdateConfigurationSetSendingEnabled.documentation:
Enables or disables email sending for messages sent using a specific configuration set in a given AWS Region. You can use this operation in conjunction with Amazon CloudWatch alarms to temporarily pause email sending for a configuration set when the reputation metrics for that configuration set (such as your bounce on complaint rate) exceed certain thresholds.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.

SendCustomVerificationEmail.documentation:
Adds an email address to the list of identities for your Amazon SES account in the current AWS Region and attempts to verify it. As a result of executing this operation, a customized verification email is sent to the specified address.

To use this operation, you must first create a custom verification email template. For more information about creating and using custom verification email templates, see Using Custom Verification Email Templates in the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

You can execute this operation no more than once per second.
